posts.name: Emmanuel Perez
posts.cooked:
Hey FRC Community, Im just about to use again the YAGSL library and all thanks to it work a lot for us. I was just trying to config my settings and when i put the offset value at the “Adjusted Absolute Encoder” it didnt change and was the same as the “Raw Absolute Encoder” (this with each module)  just as seen on this video .

TBH I think it may be a wrong gear ratio or conversion factor I didn’t set up correctly, but we are using the Swerve X (Flipped 6.55:1 Belt Ratio, with NEOS, SPARK MAX, and the ThriftyBot Abs Encoder)

Also for some reason some of the modules in an specific moment at the JoyStick start like shaking off one side to another like if it were a PID problem, you can also see it at the vid (idk if its a pid problem or cause the offset situation).

If someone also passed by something similar pls help, thnx. Here’s my code .

posts.name: Emmanuel Perez
posts.cooked: it is plug to the analog in as it is shown on the thrifty manual, and let me check your corrections and i’ll tell, thnx for the help

posts.name: Emmanuel Perez
posts.cooked:
Already updated it but it still has the same problem as the vid, the encoder adjusted and raw value is the same even tho with the offset and it also suddenly shakes like in this new video with the frc web components POV.

Here’s the updated code .

I saw this problem last night and it was a result of some refractoring we did for 2025. Can you use this function to turn off swerve module state optimization and send another video

declaration: package: swervelib, class: SwerveModule

Set this to false

link_counts.title: SwerveModule (Yet Another Generic Swerve Library API)

posts.cooked:
Nvm, found your problem. This is the wrong order.

"frontright.json",

"backright.json",

"backleft.json",

"frontleft.json"

]

Its supposed to be like this

"frontleft.json",

"frontright.json",

"backleft.json",

"backright.json"

It is supposed to be like this bc of how SwerveDriveKinematics work

posts.name: Emmanuel Perez
posts.cooked:
You are right, yesterday after making my last post I saw at the Web Components that there were modules that were in wrong positions and I changed it, but I still have some problems with two of the modules (don’t follow even close to the instructions), but I also found something strange that happend with my offsets:

When I set the offsets that my dashboard is marking and then load the code, even if i have my steering wheel where i first config the offset now it changes to another value, and I saw that they have a relation.

Just to give one of the values it gaved me as an example, on the frontright offset (before deploying code) at the dashboard i had 351 … of value, and at my code i had 287 , changed it and deployed the code with the changes with offset value of 351 , but now it changed my offset value at the dashboard and it changed to 287 . If we try to change again the offset it will always exchange places between this two numbers. Having always a relation between the values of:

FrontRight Difference: 69

Front Left Difference: 80

BackRight Difference: 131

BackLeft Difference: 85

TBH I dont know if what you said of turning false the optimization is related to that, and I still dont know why my adjusted and my raw is the same when last year the adjusted had the difference that was substracted. Here’s a video where I show you what happens.

Later I’ll try turning off the optimization if this solves the problem. Tell you some more news later, thanks!

That is a bug, thank you for pointing it out! (I had improperly fixed it) The problem was that the raw absolute encoder value was the same bc the cache read the adjusted value. Can you update to 2025.3.0-beta3 , i just pushed the update.

For now you have to set the offsets to 0, then get the absolute encoder value, unless you update to beta3

posts.name: Emmanuel Perez
posts.cooked: In fact It now works correcctly, thank your so much Nstrike, rigfht now i just have some problems following instructions but I think it’s either/both nav-x problems or pid problems.
Can you send a video of your new problem?

posts.name: Emmanuel Perez
posts.cooked:
give me time, my mechanics team just grabbed the chassis to improve it and make it more stable, heres a vid before modifications (centering the battery).

PS: We’ll secure the mats, cause they moved with the swerve.
Without anymore context that looks fine to me. Also that battery is having the time of its life

posts.name: Jeremy Chaney
posts.cooked:
We’re still having issues getting the angle control of our swerve drive using the 2025.3.0 version of YAGSL (didn’t see this thread until about 4-ish hours into debug today).

We had this all 100% functional on the 2024 release of YAGSL but even after copying over the same offsets, gear ratios, and factors related to the angle motors, we can’t seem to get the motors to drive straight.

This is our first year using swerve so just to show our work, we’re using a MK4i Swerve Module so we used a gear ratio of 21.43 (because it’s 150/7:1) and a factor of 16.8 (because 360/21.43)

To find the angle offsets we oriented all wheels with the gears on the left and observed the numbers of “Adjusted Absolute Encoder” dumped into SmartDashboard for each wheel and copied that value into the absoluteEncoderOffset field for each wheel’s corresponding json file.

The behavior we’re seeing is we can’t get wheels to reliably face forward when driving straight forward on blocks, we also see some angles about 180 degrees apart where the angle seems to be glitching between wanting to continue rotating or jumping back 180 degrees.

link_counts.title: MK4i Swerve Module – Swerve Drive Specialties

posts.cooked:
JChaney:

numbers of “Adjusted Absolute Encoder”

You are supposed to use Raw Absolute Encoders and can you link to your code?

posts.name: Jeremy Chaney
posts.cooked: Thanks, will instruct students to try that Monday… we don’t have our code in a public repo (school district blocks github so it’s tricky to do stuff there, library updates are a whole other headache haha) but it’s essentially the YAGSL Example from last Saturday with our parameters added to the *.json files. We made the update today to use the yagsl-2025.3.0.json file as well as the updates to Vision.java and Robot.java described in today’s commit

link_counts.title: GitHub - BroncBotz3481/YAGSL-Example: Yet Another General Swerve Library Example Project

posts.cooked: Could you post your code with the json files

posts.name: Jeremy Chaney
posts.cooked:
Sure thing, this should be roughly the same as the example from github with our JSON parameters added (whole workspace was too large to upload here)

main.zip (127.3 KB)
Can you create a gh repo instead?

posts.name: Jeremy Chaney
posts.cooked: (Solved for us) Talking with @nstrike , they suggested changing the proportional PID constant for the angle to 0.01 (was 0.0020645 by default from YAGSL GH example) in pidfproperties.json. This solved it, we also used AdvantageScope to compare the actual encoder positions against the desired positions (determined by the controller input) and it was the lag between the two that prompted this change, if you’re seeing a lag, I recommend this change.
